item.title: Shop For DSL and Other Broadband Options Easily
item.description: Frustrated with unreliable internet or sluggish dial-up? Now’s the perfect time to explore new DSL and broadband choices, thanks to an improved online tool. Shop for DSL, the innovative search engine, has been enhanced for user-friendliness and comprehensiveness. This real-time tool pinpoints broadband options specific to your location and neatly categorizes them for easy browsing. What makes this service stand out is its location-based approach. Broadband availability, particularly for DSL and Cable, hinges on your exact location.

item.title: PRI over Cable Cost Savings
item.description: Many businesses use ISDN PRI, a technology that bundles multiple phone lines onto a single digital cable, for cost-effective phone service. While initially implemented with T1 lines, offering 23 usable voice channels after reserving one for signaling, ISDN PRI can now be delivered over cable networks. Modern phone systems, including PBX and key systems, typically support ISDN PRI, allowing businesses to scale their phone lines up to 46, 69, 92, or more.

item.title: Triple Play For Business
item.description: A popular trend in consumer telecommunications, the “residential triple play,” bundles television, telephone, and broadband internet services. This package is offered at a lower cost than purchasing these services individually from separate providers. Cable companies are well-positioned to provide this bundle due to the high bandwidth capacity of their Hybrid Fiber Cable (HFC) infrastructure, although telephone and wireless providers also offer similar packages. Businesses also benefit from triple play bundles. Comcast, a major provider known for its cable TV and broadband services, also ranks as the third largest phone company in the United States.

item.title: HFC Broadband For Business
item.description: Many small businesses don’t fit into the “residential” user category but don’t require or can’t afford expensive traditional business telecom services like T1 lines or Ethernet over Copper. One solution is HFC, or Hybrid Fiber Coax, broadband services. You might know this as “Cable broadband for business.” Many home-based businesses successfully use it to manage websites, access online information, and send and receive emails. item.title: Triple Play Helps Wireline Fight Satellite
item.description: The market for television services is completely saturated. While getting TV used to be simple, viewers now have a wide range of options, including over-the-air, cable, satellite, telco (AT&T), and fiber optic (Verizon). The recent discontinuation of analog television transmissions was met with indifference by most, except for a small number of consumers who didn’t buy a converter or new digital TV. Now, these individuals are rushing to find converter boxes or signing up with cable or satellite providers like DirecTV or Dish Network.
